description.text:
Wire Box can store and dispense wire. Wire can be pulled out to length and cut. The boxes can be stacked for storage. I have included two sized boxes for 1-1/2" OD spools and 2-1/4" OD spools. Also included are the spools if you need them.

As always, I have included the 123D Design files so you can modify these to meet your needs.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Notes:

I used PLA filament.

If you would like to make the boxes stackable, I have included Box Bottoms. The Box Bottoms are glued on the bottom of the box. The Box Bottom is smaller than the box (see picture) and fits into the open top of a box below. Glue the Box Bottom in the center of the bottom.

The Spools are printed in two parts and need to be glued together. I made the fit tight so you may need to sand, file or scrape the hole so the parts fit together. I use an exacto knife and scraped the inside edge until the parts fit snugly.

Box Bottom glued to the bottom.

title: Monoprice MP Select Mini Filament Guide

description.text:
2016-10-16 - Someone remarked that this filament guide still works fine with the filament filter (available elsewhere). He said the filter just rides between the guide and the extruder.

2016-09-22 - I had a suggestion in the Facebook group to add a piece of nylon tape to the guide where the filament rubs against it. This would be to prevent wear. So far I'm content without it, and haven't noticed much wear. YMMV.

2016-09-20 - I had a report that this model wasn't printing well. I believe I traced this to an old .stl being uploaded. I believe I fixed the model. Let me know if not.

This borrows from jasonjones' Filter Bar and converts it to a filament guide for those who do not wish to use a filter. Like the original, it uses the stock screws with washers. I noticed that, with the stock filament spool holder, the filament rakes across the curved edge of the z-axis tower, and enters the extruder at a strange angle. I figured a filament guide might take some pressure off the filament as well as guiding it straight into the extruder.

I let my filament feed off of the front side of the spool. I haven't tested this with rear feed.

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-40%
Modified the original using Tinkercad.

comments.text:
Printed like a champ.
I didn't have the filter, so unfortunately the filament was going in at an angle made the extruder gears pretty unhappy. Maybe it was a combination of the spool location and that it was near the end of the roll.

print_settings.Notes:: If you want it to rattle add chopped filament in the tail between the 65-80% print mark.

description.text:
I wanted to make my own snake design, and after 3 or 4 prototypes and redesigns it's finally ready to share. Compared to some other snakes on here I checked out it's not quite as flexible but has less open space. So I think it's a good compromise between realistic and flexible.

The tail prints hollow so you need to add rattles to it during the print. I just used chopped up filament, which seems to work well. I messed with the idea of printed rattles but they just weren't loud enough. If you look through the pics you can see the rattles inside one of the blue tails. If you do add filament as your rattles don't add them too soon or your cooling fan just blows them around. fill the tail 1/4 to 1/2 full for a decent sounding rattle snake.

I've included the components to create your own length of snake so see how long you can get it. I did one that was about 34 inches. Make sure to add it to the made section.

BTW. these snakes make AWESOME bath toys for the kids. They'll float and wiggle in the turbulence of the water.

Also, this snake cannot be assembled after they are printed. you'll have to layout the components in your slicing software to get a customized length.

ScDc3D Printing

Notes:

Layer: .2mm
Infill: 10-20%
Supports: off
Raft: off
Retraction: on

You'll have to brake the joints free in some places, retraction and Z hop help with this a little. I run without raft on glass heated bed sprayed with Aquanet. I have not tried to print in anything other than PLA but the overhang is pretty steep in some areas.

If you want it to rattle add chopped filament in the tail between the 65-80% print mark.

The flip out L shaped cable winding fixture on Apples power bricks.

Fan Duct for the 'original' 50mm Ultimaker fan, with donut-shaped cooling area around the nozzle. 
This is a derivative of Geo Hagen's well designed Fan Duct (www.thingiverse.com/thing:16624) and Owen's great Fan Duct (www.thingiverse.com/thing:13625)
Printed in PLA, no support or raft needed.
20120219 Added a lower resolution STL file with less polygons.

Just print it aligned flat on the fan mounting flange. No support or raft needed. Prints well in PLA, does not melt.
Best to rework the holes with 3.2mm drill (just by hand) to make sure the screws fit nicely.

comments.text: Although it looks pretty, the design is useles if you ask me. I've just printed it. I had my doubts about whether the duct is wide enough to be not obtrusive to the flow of air. As it seems, more air is coming out from the back of the fan itself, than at the end of the nozzle. Probably because the duct is too much of a funnel becoming too narrow. With a quick wet finger test it also seems that almost no air is coming out on the left side (relative to the image shown above) at the nozzle.

comments.text:
Just some ideas:
Try printing it in polycarbonate or one of the other highest temp plastics, so it's melt temp is above the normal printing temps..
Put kapton tape on the nozzle and heater block, and another layer on the duct. You could even use a layer of kapton or even a thin metal shield between the extruder and duct, and then divert a small amount of air between the duct and shield to keep it cool.
The top of the duct is fairly simple. Just get a circle of shim metal, drill a hole, then form the cone. Then print the rest of the duct and glue the metal on, just have a metal top part where it's closest to the nozzle. It'll act as a heat sink and spread the heat, and shouldn't get to melt temps where you glue it further away. You could easily print two blocks with a cone within a cone, and form it in a vise or press.

(NOTE: Pic is from my AA holder) That said, this is just a triple A holder I use for my rechargeables to keep track of which ones are good and which are dead. This was one of my first dual extrusion designs and prints, so that explains the amount of black that bled into the red. I've also included the sketchup file if you'd like to edit it. I have scaled the model in sketchup to make 10.5mm holes which match a AAA battery. I have no need for it so I haven't printed and tested it myself, but had a comment about wanting one, so figured i'd post it. According to sketchup, it should be scaled perfectly...

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

20

Notes:

For anyone using the flashforge creator pro and simplify3d, I use the following script to get much cleaner prints (now that I've learned from this color bleed lol). Adds more time as it lets one side cool down upon tool change, but it's worth it. I printed in abs, so if you're printing in PLA you will have to adjust the temps.... Just go to process settings, scripts, tool change script and copy the following.

; Tool chance script start
G1 X120 Y-70 F4000 ; Move out of the way while it stabilises active tool temp.
{IF NEWTOOL=0}; RIGHT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S160 T1; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T1)
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S230 T0; Heat active extruder to 210c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M133 T0; Stabilise T0 temperature
{IF NEWTOOL=1}; LEFT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S160 T0; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T0)
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S230 T1; Heat active extruder to 230c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M133 T1; Stabilise T1 temperature
; Tool chance script end

comments.text:
I haven't tried that, I just used support. If you have S3d (Simplify 3D) you can add/delete support so you only have it under the keychain loop and under the top half of tire tread (to get it started).
If your using Repetier you might have to play with the "support" settings: Go to the "slicer" tab, click "configuration" and the left half of the screen will populate with the CuraEngine Settings. Under the "Print" tab you will find 5 more tabs, click "structures" then scroll down to "support". For normal prints on my TinyBoy I have mine set at: lines, Overhang 60, Fill Amount 15, Distance XY 1, and Distance Z .2 . To get the supports where you want them, you might increase Overhang, and increase Fill Amount. Maybe even switch between "lines" and "grid" to see which gives the best looking support. Its a pretty small print and doesnt use up much plastic so dont be afraid to play around with the settings. Good luck and happy printing!

I reworked Juancgarcia's Sword of Omens Dagger into the full powered version. Added the blade. It was designed for a 1/4 in dowel rod to strengthen the blade. There are two options for the crossguard - halves or whole.
Any input is appreciated.

2-13: New Blade design. I know the part that goes into the guard is a bit dogey but it should work just fine with some sanding. Added full crossguard. Plug on grip A will need sanding to fit properly into B but it doesn't take much

2-23 Final version. Longer blade. I recommend adding some pennies wrapped in tape to Grip A for proper balance I used around 15 for mine

Added separate files for the blade sections and the closed version of the Eye

comments.text:
I love this! Surprised nobody has uploaded make pics yet. Just started printing mine - I'll be sure to upload pics when it's done.
As an aside, I took the crossguard and chopped it in half the opposite direction from what you did so that it can print laying down. That way the only support needed will be on the inside instead of underneath. Should make it easier to clean up and sand.
I'm giving some thought to installing electronics but not sure what kind of sound would be good. I'd like the roar the sword always made but I haven't been able to find a sound clip of it without background music.

I haven't put in electronics in mine although I want to make one with that in mind.  I have a custom lightsaber so I may use the electronics from one of them for sound.  I know Larry Kenny has done the call in several interviews so you may be able to find it in one of them.  I haven't taken the time to isolate it yet but it is on my ever increasing list of things to do.  I'd love to see yours when you get finished.  Oh and be careful with the tips on the hooks. comments.author: Sehven

comments.text:
I don't mean the "thunder thunder thunder." I mean that roar sound the sword makes. I understand if you don't know what I mean: I didn't even notice that's what it was until years later. It's heavily synthesized. It's the sound that plays at the very end of the into song and it plays every time he makes the signal. The problem is there's always music playing over it so I've never found a clean audio file for it.
My crossguard came out pretty good but I had the same problem with the eye that somebody else mentioned. Simplify3d took forever to slice it and when it was done, it looked like it was trying to print it inside out or something. I aborted the print before it finished but it looked like it was on track to look exactly like the previous pics. After trying for a while to figure out a way to fix the file for slicing, I gave up and just created my own. I mean it's just a some with the Thundercat logo engraved in so I find an SVG of the logo, modeled a quick dome, and recessed it into it. Did a quick low res test print to make sure it would work the way I expected and it did. Printing the blade now: gonna take all day.
comments.author: omicron22

comments.text: I missed the part where you said roar.  I haven't found a good copy yet myself.  I have a few sources I'll ask and if they have anything useable I'll share them.  I'm not sure why people are having difficulties slicing the eye.  I've used Cura, slic3r and the XYZ slicer without issue.
comments.author: Sehven

comments.text: Weird. Having trouble with grip b as well. It's trying to slice it with a gap between the handle and pommel (like it's just skipping a section of handle) and rounding the pommel on both sides. Guess I'll have to model my own for that as well. Blade came out nice but I have to say I don't care for the... I don't know what you call it: the point above the crossguard. I don't like how it sticks straight up instead of tapering in toward the blade. It's a minor quibble but I think I'll remodel that part as well.
comments.author: omicron22

comments.text: I think the technical term would be langets.  I thought I redid them to taper down some. I just ended up sanding mine down.
comments.author: Sehven

comments.text: Sounds good. I found the problem with the grip. The pommel and the little round jewels in it were all solid meshes that continued through the body of the handle. I guess some slicers can handle overlapping meshes but it seems that simplify3d isn't one of them. I managed to separate them and then use a Boolean in blender to join them into a single solid mesh. I'll try printing it tonight if I have time. I also brought in the langets and am going to print the bottom section of the blade again (I was worried that trying to sand them down would just cut right into the open infill space). Once I've confirmed that all the modified parts print well, I'll send you the files.

description.text: character project

2x this object plus a strut in between makes a spool holder which clips to the top of a Prusa i3 LC frame. May also work with aluminium frame - not tested.  
UPDATE 13/02/14 - Changed the width of the mounts to prevent bending.
Update 16/04/2016 - Added hole for bolt and nut for clamping to frame.
Update 24/07/2016 - Added v3 of spoolholder, skeletonised design - less plastic and faster printing.
Made in sketchup, exported as stl.

description.text: Sons_of_the_Harpy_Mask mix from and obj file, i just close the holes and made thicker the mask so it can be printed at 4cm

Replacement print for a 2006 Chevrolet automatic transmission button. Somehow the lower tab snapped off my button, so naturally I had to print a replacement. Printed in ABS and smoothed using Acetone for the shiny finish.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Material: Black ABS
Nozzle Temperature: 245°C
Bed Temperature: 100°C
Bed: Glass + Hairspray

Acetone Smoothing
  • Tall Large Ikea Pruta Food Container (http://www.ikea.com/ca/en/catalog/products/60149673/) (or any suitably sized Polypropylene container).
  • 4 Paper towels cut to size and draped down each side of container touching the bottom to wick up liquid.
  • 80mL Acetone soaking paper towels (pure 100% acetone nail polish remover from local store).
  • Part hung via packing twine not touching sides.
  • Vapour exposure time: 45min.

*Note: Acetone vapour is highly flammable, I did this outdoors.
Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS): http://www.sciencelab.com/msds.php?msdsId=9927062

comments.text: Printed one and it popped right in. Perfect. Been missing that for years now. Thank you.

comments.text: Mine broke in the same way and this is a great solution, thanks!

comments.text:
I see it is one file still, but I managed to separate them.
It seems they are 0.42mm off the base, which can make a messy print if you don't spot it and bring it down to zero.
Also the box is the wrong way up for printing.
Also the box is about 1 degree off level, similarly very annoying if you don't spot it.
Hope that helps.
comments.author: RevK

comments.text: Hi, thanks for the case!  Could you upload each piece in a separate file so that the cover can be printed in a different orientation?
comments.author: yellolegalpad

comments.text: Sure I will upload it tonight.
comments.author: yellolegalpad

description.text:
I wanted a spool holder that mounts securely to the Robo3d printer, had different size spacers to fit different size spools and it would be quick to print new sizes if needed, and spins with little resistance. It is a work in progress, but can be upgraded easily.

This will accept up to a 95mm wide filament spool.

It has two mounts that you can rotate to secure to the top of the unit to hold it in place. It has an easy to remove spindle which you can print different size spacers to fit any filament roll. It spins with little resistance using PETG filament, but should work fine with others. You will need eight 2.7mm screws that are 12mm long to secure it together. I made some slight changes after I made mine, so it will look a little different than the picture.

The dot on the rollers indicates the lowest position for the spacer. I wanted to give a little room for forgiveness on the size that is why I designed it this way.

I hope you like it.

Update 09-26-2016
Found out that the sizes were wrong on the spacers, so I have updated with the correct parts. This covers 31, 32, 51, 52, 53 and 54mm center diameter. Let me know if these work for you.

Update 09-29-2016
Updated the width of the holder to 95mm.

Update 10-06-2-16
Updated Spool to 95mm only and changed the description.

title: MKS SBASE Conversion kit for Monoprice Maker Select (Wanhao i3)

description.text:
This is a conversion kit. I had purchased a Monoprice Maker Select, which is a rebranded Wanhao i3. The electronics had failed me at some point and i decided to upgrade to a MKS SBASE, which is a Smoothieboard clone. The original electronics were a Melzi board.

This kit helps with mounting the electronics and replacing the front and back plate to accomodate feedthroughs and a new gLCD.

Additional parts needed:

  • USB Extender: https://amzn.com/B00H8RX780
    o This is for breaking out the usb
  • gLCD: https://amzn.com/B00THZK5JU
    o The original LCD was really nice, and much higher quality than what i'm linking, but the SBASE doesnt have the header for it. Thus, going for new electronics. Make sure to read my review. The gLCD sold here has reversed shrouds.
  • MKS SBASE: https://amzn.com/B01FVT5VA8
    o This is the new electronics we will be mounting.

Print:
1x smoothiepanel_spacer.stl : Used between the lcd and the backplate.
1x smoothiepanel.stl : This is where the lcd will mount onto. There is room for the knob and the emergency stop switch.
1x smoothiepanel_REAR.stl : This is was redesigned to add a USB port, and shift the power connector. I considered also adding the ethernet port to this panel, but could not find an extender for the usb that didnt obstruct the ethernet port.
2x smoothiepanel_mount.stl : These are 'wings' that will mount to either side of the MKS SBASE board to then fit in the same place that the melzi board was mounted into.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

The new version of the Fly6 rear bike camera from Cycliq (a great product!) is the Fly6[v] (as of September 2016) and it uses a simple velcro strap that is incompatible with previous Fly6 mounts. This is an awesome mounting solution for the back of a seatpost, but I ride with large bags on a rear rack that obscure the view.

This bracket is compatible with rear bike rack mounts that have 2 holes with 2" spacing, and I've added two more holes that are also on my Topeak rack. The holes are designed for M5 socket head cap screws.

I plan to use it with a simple little tether (maybe zip ties around the rack and light with a carabiner) in case the mount fails on the road. 5mm of the "strong and flexible" material is very robust though -- I couldn't crack or flex it by pushing on the middle while pulling down on both wings very hard. Still, it could become far more brittle outdoors with constant vibrations, so it's best to be safe with a tether.

I really like having the strap go through a slot for security (so there's no way the camera can slide off the top) but you can't pull a hooked strap past the loop part of the hook and loop fastener. I solved that problem with a bit of tape defeating the loop area inside the slot (shown in the picture). Ideally, you'd simply design the hook and loop strap to avoid that area, but it's not worth my time. Anyway, the tape is hidden between the straps and inside the slot, so it won't get dirty or weathered or otherwise look bad.

Here's a link to the bracket at Shapeways. I've marked it up $0.57 to see if I can recoup the cost of my first failed version, but feel free to download the files and have it printed yourself if you'd prefer.

iframe width="625" height="652" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" src="//www.shapeways.com/fragments/product?spin=HKK7A7ULK"

I strongly suggest printing in black material to help with UV protection (the black coloring blocks UV at or near the surface). I chose the "strong and flexible" nylon material from Shapeways. ABS or PLA will likely work all right, but definitely rig up a tether as UV exposure will break them down faster (hundreds of times faster if the bike is stored in the sun!)

title: Realacc X210 (Lumenier QAV-X) Actioncam mount (GoPro Session) V1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Since the original Realacc X210 actioncam mount isn't very well designed (plate breaks away), I designed this actioncam mount which is beeing held in place by the already existing screws.

This mount hasn't been tested with a GoPro Session, since I don't own one but feel free to do so and give me some improvement info (if necessary).

Tested the other Version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1766004) with semi-rigid/flex material from Real (Bioflex) and it works perfect. Crash resistence was the main concern but also in hard crashes, the go pro is held in place and the mount is not breaking.
You can use rigid material like PETG too, but certainly will break sooner on harder crashes. Haven't tested the soft version (Ninjaflex) yet, may be can be beneficial for vibration compensation. However, the semi-rigid Filament is too hard to provide vibration dampening, but usually this isn't necessary on good tuned quads.

Can be printed with and without support. Comes out a little bit nicer with support.

Not sure if this will fit the Lumenier QAV-X? Just tested in on the Realacc X210 from Banggood.

Enjoy.

This is the template for the tiles to play the game "Quirkle". You will need to print these six tiles 18 times to have a full set of 108. After printing, you will need to either paint or color the shapes within the tiles. There will be three of each color and shape. Example: three red circles, three orange circles, three blue circles, etc. For game rules, see:
http://www.ultraqwirkle.com/game-rules.php

Original game was designed by Susan McKinley Ross and published by MindWare in 2006.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ayNFsZZu6u0

In downtown Sioux Falls, SD is a wonderful gift shop called Zandbroz Variety. It has all kinds of beautiful and fascinating things. In the rear of the store, behind an actual drug store soda counter, is a small antiques and vintage area.

I almost always find things to photograph there. Lately, I've found many more things that caught my eye and would make great subjects to 3D model.

This architectural salvage fragment is from a former Shrine Temple. It shows the Shriners logo. I'm sure it was a mass produced item, but I'm not too sure what it is made of (terra-cotta or tinted concrete)? It is about 12 inches (30 cm) on a side. It was heavy too.

I pulled out my trust iPhone 6 Plus after carrying this block to a spot with indirect lighting. I then circled it, taking snapshots. I took some closeups of the more detailed parts of the block, such as the sphinx, the star and the scimitar. Altogether, I took about 58 photos of the block from various directions and distances.

At home, I downloaded the photos and checked them for sharpness. Any blurry shots would have been discarded, but luckily I didn't have any.

In Photoscan, I opened the folder containing all the JPEG photos I'd taken and used the 'High' setting at each step of the process. I exported the completed mesh into Meshmixer to do some fine-tuning in a few spots that had unexpected artifacts. I then imported the corrected mesh back into Photoscan to texture map as a final step. For the texture mapping, I chose to use 8192, along with color averaging to get a more balanced exposure without weird color shifts.

Surprisingly, this model only took about two hours to create!

title: Coil Concept Exploration
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The coil shown is just an exploration into generating 3D printed inductive coils with OpenSCAD.

I am publishing this thing collection to illustrate concepts in creating 3D printed magnetics and coils. The effort is primarily intended for single-extruder printers because that is the most widely used type of printer (plus it's what I have).

The first concept involves the use of voids in an otherwise solid shape. If these voids are spiral in nature like a perfectly wound coil of wire then they can actually touch and still work as a lower performance coil. This principle is due to the fact that 3D printed coils have resistance higher than wires.

If we use copper in our perfect coil then any touch between the wires "shorts out" the coil because the wire has such high conductivity. 3D printed wires, however, have resistance so that the main channels of circular cross-section have lower resistance due to their width. However the "plus" shaped voids between them are insulators and the tips of the "plus" shaped voids define very narrow channels between the wires. These narrow channels have higher resistance so they don't really "short out" the coil. They do degrade performance, but not all that much as long as the wires are large in cross-section and the channels between them are small.

Another key element in this coil concept is that the touches between the wires are what makes the shape printable. So we can print perfectly imperfect coils in one material using one nozzle. These coils will have high resistance, but for some applications that is desired.

For example if using inductive power to drive an LED we use a coil, a capacitor, and an LED with all three connected in parallel. It may be that the resistance of the coil is desired to keep the LED from destruction in the presence of strong magnetic fields.

This is a work i progress and I am posting it here to assign an open source license to the concepts if that is possible. Also please note that I could be totally wrong about this idea as it is untested at this time. I'll keep you posted. :)

Les

comments.text: I found that the coil printed correctly firs time and the turns were bound together by a small line width.  Then I was able to easily separate the turns to make a slinky-like separated coil.  This will fit nicely into a magnetic iron spacer core!

title: How to make a Radar Station with Arduino and Processing

description.text:
Originally written by Dejan Nedelkovski

In this Arduino Tutorial I will show you how you can make this cool looking radar using the Arduino Board and the Processing Development Environment. You can watch the following video or read the written tutorial below for more details.

You may use Fusion PCB service (https://www.seeedstudio.com/fusion.html) to make it better.

Building the device

First I made a cardboard stand for connecting the Ultrasonic sensor to the Servo motor. I folded it like it’s shown on the picture below, glued it and secured to the servo motor using a screw like this.

Also I attached a pin header on which I soldered 4 jumper wires for connecting the sensor.
Arduino-Radar-Pin-Hearder

Finally I secured the servo motor to the Arduino Board using an elastic band.

Circuit Schematics

I connected the Ultrasonic Sensor HC-SR04 to the pins number 10 and 11 and the servo motor to the pin number 12 on the Arduino Board.

Source codes

Now we need to make a code and upload it to the Arduino Board that will enable the interaction between the Arduino and the Processing IDE.

to read more about the code, please click this link:
http://seeed.cc/project_detail.html?id=1846

Fusion PCB & PCBA Service

https://www.seeedstudio.com/fusion.html

This is a base plate for a payload that offers stability and drag for deceleration. Holes exist in the arms of the shape to allow for easy pass through of parachute lines. The center bore allows for an MCU and other components to sit below the shape, making for a lower center of gravity.

There is another file which contains one fourth of the whole shape to fit on smaller printers. Of course, print 4 of them and then glue together for full shape.

I have also included another file. It features the base plate and a cup. The cup should be placed inside the hole to carry any electronics that will be on board. The plastic cup was made by Alexander Trushkin.

Current view is of the bottom of the plate.

Made 9/18/2016 for a Space Hardware Club project at the University of Alabama in Huntsville by Matthew Methe.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8Jw6FPdvr87

1)Print one Castor Cup per castor/roller on the piece of furniture you wish to use them on.
Suggested print settings: 0.2mm layer height, 30% infill, no supports. 2) Purchase a set of adhesive rubber bumpers like shown in the picture (found on the cheap at any local hardware/big box store). 3) Use at least 3 bumpers per castor cup to provide extra gription and ensure your furniture does not roll around when in use. 4) Enjoy the sweet life!

title: Mouse Car: Son of Rat Racer

description.text: Print some accessories to to attach to a mousetrap and turn it into a spring-loaded car! Note that although the car assembled and the mechanism works, the spring mechanism provies way too much torque. The wheels spin too fast and end up slipping in place. Eventually, it slows down enough to move a foot or two. Much more detailed information is available on this blog post: http://netninja.com/2013/11/04/son-of-ratracer-mouse-car/ Download mousecar-src.zip for the OpenSCAD source for all three components.

• Print two end caps, two axles, and two pairs of wheels.
  • You will have to provide your own mousetrap. This is sized to the Victor brand mousetrap. Alter the OpenSCAD source files if yours has other dimensions.
  • Use pliers to remove the "cheese platform" trigger and retaining bar from the base. You should just have the spring-loaded U bar remaining.
  • Attach the end caps.
  • Push an axle through each end cap.
  • Attach the wheels
  • Tie a string to the rat trap's U-bar
    • Pull back the U-bar and, while carefully holding it down and not releasing it onto your fingers, thread the string through the hole in the axle. Wind it around the axle. Put the car on the floor. Quickly release the snappy part. In theory, the string is pulled, spinning the axle and wheels, making the car go.

title: SYSGRO7_hexwall
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Structural 3D-Wall.Planting pots, shelfes, electronics,Lights joinable to connect to a wall. Just tried to keep it as simple as possible for 3d printing.
Easy to expand in sizre an function. Adding pumps, lights and other electronics should be not so hard.
A hexwall_pot is 140mm wide.

I am still printing a few parts and i have to put them together for a working prototype to show pictures. So far everything worked as thought.

Printer:

Spili Blue

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

No use of going too fine

Infill:

as you like

Notes:

Place the pots on the backside for slicing.The thing needs a little support at the two hexagonal outlets, maybe inlets too else no support needed,

Remove Supports, maybe sand off a little from the outlets, just make then fit.Punch or drill the holes in the outlets, where you need the water to flow through.
And dont forget to make it watertight.

I was bored.

MATERIAL

One basic pot needs about 90 Gramms of ABS.
A PVC Pipe, 52mm diameter, standardpipe
Pump,Hose, Tank,Connectors
Solarcells,windturbine,waterwheel, Batteries
Screws

PLAN YOUR HEXWALL

It is always good to make a plan. What is the main goal? A full planting Wall? a few Plants and a shelf? Draw a sketch and think where to start if you want to expand it later.
When water goes in, where does it go through, are all holes open on its way down?

THE PIPE

Print the Schablone twice or more, Use one or two 8mm rods and fix them 140mm apart and use this to cut, mill, drill the right numbers of slots. See the drawing for measurements.

SHELF

See the drawing for measurements. The slot has 10mm.

MONTAGE

Screw the wallfixes at the their place on the wall. To hold the pieces to each other push a joint in the holes on the back where they meet. It is possible to screw them down to give extra strength.
It is not necessairy to use a joint at each meetingpoint, sometimes one is enough, you have to try yourself.
After finishing the montage of your SYSGRO7_Hexwall you can hang it on the wallfixes. It is also possible to let the wall hang from the top/ceiling.

author: Skopix

title: Raspberry Pi Bramble Rack Support and Connect

description.text:
Design of a Raspberry Pi cluster required a rack or support. Taking the initial concept from thing:30563, the support uses the RCA Video and Audio plugs to hold the circuit board on edge. This support has the following advantages.
1) The hole for the audio connector is sloted, so that manufacturing variations for the distance between the RCA Video and Audio are not a problem.
2) Air gaps in the support can allow for more passive air flow around the circuit board. The other changes were to the distance between the mounting holes to fit a Rack Mounted Canterlever tray that can be purchased from RS. The supports can be connected together using the BrambleConnect part. Alternatively attach to an enclosure using 4mm bolts.

Printed on an UP Plus using genuine fillament gives the best result. Using non-genuine fillament may require filing back any excess plastic from the RCA Video round hole (use a 21/64", or 8.3mm drill bit). Also the dove tail connections may need filing.  
Assemble using the BrambleConnect part that connects three Supports together through the base plate of a Canterlever tray,RS rack,19in,400mm dp ( RS Stock No. 433-7334 available in Australia ).  
The BrambleConnect part is single use and will tend to break if removed from the BrambleSupport part.

title: Acrylic GEEETech Prusa i3 Anti-Wobble Bracket

description.text:
This is a bracket designed to fix the Z axis wobble issue on Acrylic GEEETech printers. It was originally designed by ronindev, though I've modified it to work with my (and possibly your) printer. Notice how my printer's rail slider bearings have a lip below the carriage. This would have rendered ronindev's bracket ineffective. This remix material in place to compensate for this. I've included the OpenSCAD file for reference.

I an issue with Z-Offset. When adding the spacers it actually raises the whole carriage assembly up. I raised my build plate to compensate, but then my springs weren't compressed much at all. I added three washers (that came with the kit) below the spring to compress them more and haven't had an issue since. I'd really recommend printing spacers for it, though, as adding three washers at once is quite the ordeal. I may add spacers to this thing in the near future.

The photo of the cubes is before and after the brackets were applied.

comments.author: babokaj

comments.text: You're quite welcome! It made a world of difference for my prints, I must have some pretty bent threaded rods.
comments.author: babokaj

comments.text: Mine was good to start with, now it's better :-) One small problem is the the bracket introduces an offset to Z which means that you can barely reach down to the buildplate. So I have lowered the Z steppers by 7 mm using this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37318 scaled to 7 mm in height. This introduces a new problem that you cannot reach the lower screws on the coupler without dismounting the steper, and there is also VERY little room for the lower screw heads on the coupler.
comments.author: KingJohn

comments.text: I had the same issue with the Z-Offset. I raised my build plate, but then my springs weren't compressed much at all. I added three washers (that came with the kit) below the spring to compress them more and haven't had an issue since. I'd really recommend printing spacers for it, though, as adding three washers at once is quite the ordeal. I may add spacers to this thing in the near future.

description.text: Yup, it's a magnet on a stick, but it's an awesome combination for moving / holding those pesky T-nuts behind things with precision. This one is set up for 20 mm Extrusion channels, and uses a tiny 3mm x 3mm cylindrical rare earth magnet (easy find on eBay for under $1-2). Bendable plastic is a +, I use a PLA that has a bit of flex to it, but ABS or Nylon would likely be better. I did try more complicated handles, longer sticks, etc, they just get in the way. The K.I.S.S. mantra works very well here. Enjoy!

title: The Better Mouse Trap (for a 3D Printer!)

description.text:
Hello!

Update 19Aug2017:
New STEP files uploaded, feel free to remix it, remember to share and keep it free!

You might have seen the soda bottle mousetrap (yes its one word ^_^) on YouTube...

and also this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1929

This version combines both ideas, with added printability, uses a lot less material, saving print time (2.5 hours for all parts) and recycles widely use PET bottles.

No gluing, snap on assembly, just screw onto the PET bottle and insert a coin for the lid.

The slot for coin is designed for UK two pence, low value, no one would pinch it... Will fit coinage roughly an inch diameter and <2mm thick. In case the coin feels too loose, just pad it up with a bit of paper.

Snapping on the lid to the bottle screw mount, you should expect a snug fit, smooth enough to let the lid swing freely but not too loose as to produce any significant gap...

The lid will trigger close with just 12 grams (See slow-mo video with 7g UK two pence as counter weight on lid), thus a common house mice (Female ~20g) will very likely be enough to tip it.

https://youtu.be/nQwt40hvrLI
https://youtu.be/C6EMyTaiY98
https://youtu.be/xcn0H7aAjpE

References:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_mouse
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mouse
http://www.rentokil.co.uk/mice/species/

Flip bottle holder 180 degrees to print!
Fair amount of weight reduction should be apply in printing, use as little infill as possible(30%?), apply sufficient fan cooling for screw mount...

Not Tested on Animals Yet!

comments.text: Great catch and release trap!  I've printed this twice and both have successfully caught mice each time.
comments.author: kcchen_00

comments.text:
Printed this and stuck it outside near my bird feeder. First little chap caught within an hour. it was in good shape and perfectly healthy.
I added a bit more weight than the 2p to the door in order to get it to shut everytime which may help for people getting escapees
comments.author: ropster

comments.text: Hey,
comments.author: Taffy1990

comments.text: I replaced the little part by a screw because it broke when I tried to clip the other part. I made 2 small holes on the bottle to give some air even though I think it may be not necessary. I did not get a mouse yet but if it works, that will be a perfect object for me
comments.author: amg77

comments.text: So I have made this and wanted to give a suggestion that I found helpful. When printing the part that screws onto the bottle I suggest you have an infill of 50% or better. The lid part that the sliding piece clips onto breaks very very easy without a very stiff infill. And get rid of screw part 1. It is unjoined and unprintable. The second one is perfect though.
comments.author: sempul

comments.text:
The assembly does not move after printing the the parts crack in trying to insert.
As well replaced this cracking parts with M6 screw and found out that it can't catch a mouse.
comments.author: dxtinct

comments.text: Great that you tried it out... I haven't been able to locate a test subject, so I can't say for certain this mousetrap will guarantee a bounty on mice....

comments.text: Well done sir. My hats off to you.

author: GeoSteed

description.text:
Support me on Patreon

To help me deliver quality printable terrain models:

Armored barracks

Want more like this? Check my shop:
https://www.cgtrader.com/gunslingerstudio

Presentation on Youtube: https://youtu.be/RcG3p5Nc0xk
Panning around it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z6Cr9knRzi8

Version 2: Disconnected lots of greebles to loose parts. Print what you want and glue them on. Also added guide holes for 1.75mm and 3mm filament. Cut a small piece and glue in the hole to hold the halves together.

Print two bunker halves and glue them together. You will have a small building that doubles as a barracks and a bunker. Defend it with your imperial guards, space marines, or storm troopers. Scale it down to fit battletech, dirtside or drop zone commander.

There are several different versions so you can get many bunkers that are unique. There is also a midsection you can add between the ends to make it longer.

description.text:
Made a simple solution to mount a laserpointer on my camera.
works as a charm to aim it in the night sky without having to look on the screen or through the vewfinder!
The dimension of the laserpointer is 23mm wide and the button is about 6mm wide and 3mm high.
Mine has a button on the side and a key in the rear to turn the power on or off
So if you got a similar one this will work just fine :)!

How to use.
insert it in the mount until it seats properly or just before depending on how you want to turn it on and off.
If it is seated properly you can turn it on by turning the key, if it is just before it is seated you can turn it on and off by simply pulling the laserpointer towards you and off by pushing it the opposite way.

print_settings.Notes:: Easy prints. Recommend using 3 shells to ensure the curvature on the edges is well built. Using 3 shells keeps the wall thickness thicker in areas with tighter curves.

title: GHOSTS
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
GHOSTS are simple, decorative prints for Halloween and party decoration... or just for fun any time. Two files have been provided that mount in different ways.

The wall mount type is ready off the build plate to hang over a small nail or screw head (Head size up to 6.25mm / shaft size up to 3.0mm)

The hanging type needs to be threaded to hang. Thread down through the hole in the top into one of the eyes, thread across between the eyes, then thread back up and out the top. Translucent thread is the best to use as it's almost 'invisible' but harder to thread as you can't see its end easily. The 'easier threading tip' is to thread some coloured thread first, tie it onto the translucent thread and pull it back through in place of the coloured thread (Refer to images for additional understanding of this suggestion).

Easy and fun... GHOSTS look great printed in white and glow-in-the-dark filament.

At standard scale each ghost is 110mm tall. Scale up / down to suit but bear in mind this will affect the hole / wall mount fitting.

Please refer to the instructions and images for additional information... and post images of your GHOSTS haunting your home or office....

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

3 Shells / 10% infill

Notes:

Easy prints. Recommend using 3 shells to ensure the curvature on the edges is well built. Using 3 shells keeps the wall thickness thicker in areas with tighter curves.

Just hang or wall mount your Ghost...

The wall mount type is ready off the build plate to hang over a small nail or screw head (Head size up to 6.25mm / shaft size up to 3.0mm)

The hanging type needs to be threaded to hang. Thread down through the hole in the top into one of the eyes, thread across between the eyes, then thread back up and out the top. Translucent thread is the best to use as it's almost 'invisible' but harder to thread as you can't see its end easily. The 'easier threading tip' is to thread some coloured thread first, tie it onto the translucent thread and pull it back through in place of the coloured thread (Refer to images for additional understanding of this suggestion).

description.text:
I got rid of the stock screw for the Z axis, and hung my Z motor from the top when I got myself a leadscrew. I also replaced the bearings for the Z axis with longer ones to add to the stability. In the process I made some bigger holders for these bearings.

Use as You please, maybe some holes need sanding, and drilling, but this kit fit perfect om my machine.

You can choose to leave the long bearing holders AS IS or cut away the weak parts in the middle to expose the centre. Do as You please...

I used a bearing in the bottom of the rod to take of the weight from the whole rig from the motor bearings.

The Bottom part also features a holder for a bearing if your lead screw is longer than mine...

Made to be printed with 0,5 nozzle

I have a project for which I wanted some piano keys, so I created this OpenSCAD module to create them. There's an option to label the note names on all of the white keys, but I don't have a dual extrusion machine available this weekend. I'll add a picture of labeled keys when I get a chance to print some. piano.scad is the module... it uses bitmap.scad to render the note names, if you so wish. piano_keys.scad is an example file, which prints one octave of keys, sized to easily fit just about any 3D printer, with an M3 hole at the top to put a rod through to hold them all together. Add hardware to the back of them, and you can make this part of all kinds of awesome musical projects! Options:
  • variable # of octaves
  • black keys/white keys/both
  • label notes on white keys
  • variable sizing and spacing
    • I design things in my free time, just for fun. If you like my stuff, send me some DOGE. It'll totally make my day! Thank you. D9hPusbPPdbUXgmsRqRcb7jRisVLnriCuP

1: Set options.
2: Print.
3: Sing us a song, you're the piano man.

comments.text: Do you maybe have a version of the model without the "teardrop" holes the hinge motion? I don't need the keys to be able to move, I just need something that looks like keys. I'm going to stamp the model out into a block of material in blender to make in inverted keyboard for a hologram. A solid model without the hinge would look better.
comments.author: bgareffa

comments.text: Sure, just comment out line 16 in piano_keys.scad (the one with the TearDrop() call) and recompile, and you'll have solid keys.  If you want the whole thing to be a solid block you might also want to make some other adjustments so that the whole thing is one solid piece, which would allow your inverted keyboard to be solidly concave.
comments.author: bgareffa

comments.text: I'm building a digital keyboard, and this helps tons. Curious about the width of the keys by default. The default width is 25, but how wide is that in inches?
comments.author: melih

comments.text: Awesome!  In answer to your question, 1in = 25.4 mm, so for our purposes, they are 1 inch wide by default.  If you want to know what number to put in to the script, you can either do the math yourself, or outsource it to Google, by searching for "3 inches in mm" or something like that and Google will display the answer, and some boxes to perform your own conversions.

title: Flashforge Creator Pro 2016 glass bed corner bracket

description.text:
This is a remix of a remix - basically removed the lip from omegatron's remixed corner to fit my bed+blue sticker+3.3mm glass which comes to 12-13mm total height depending on how tight I squeeze my callipers!

FreeCAD source for that included - its basically a couple of cubes made into cuts for the original mesh. It pokes above the bed (but off the bed) under 1mm.

The nut and bolt are chewbone's originals. I used ABS and still find that they don't screw very reliably - at some point you end up just turning and turning and not screwing in any tighter. When will we learn to use metal for printer parts?!

I found that as my glass is a bit larger than the bed in both X and Y, even with 3 of these you get movement, i've now got 4 in place - basically 3 tight and one loose-ish coping with the overhang, which works well.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro 2016

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Creator Pro ABS standard

Infill:

35%

Notes:

A support is only need for the corner piece.

I set my glass bed to 110c and used some hairspray.

title: Customiser, experimental: generator for splinters, basaltish columns, irregular crystals and cristalline like structures, irregular spheres, asteroids, failed planets

description.text:
Experimental generator for crystalline like structures, by harnessing a bunch of identically sized stanchions, randomly rotated around a common pivot point with a hull.
Depending on stanchion count, the structures tend to become flattish or more or less spherical. Choice of stanchion footprint shape can be used to modulate object surface.
I don't know what I'm going to use this for, but like to share it nevertheless, in case somebody else finds an application for it.
For printing, you will have to rotate the resulting object for best printability.

title: Updated E3D Chimera Hot End OpenSCAD model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Excellent OpenSCAD model of the Chimera by Professional3D, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1018787 needed some minor updates for the E3D 2016 version with heat break retaining screw holes on the side and the new sensor cartridge heater blocks.

Quick Points:

  • The new blocks in particular mean you can mount left and right blocks and the blocks don't need to be in that strange 180 degree orientation, which will help with some mount designs.
    The new blocks are ~3mm longer than before too.

  • The original modules are still in the scad file, with new _v2 versions being selected by default, with the blocks aligned the same way.

  • Most credit goes to Professional3D, this is just a minor edit really.

  • This is not really intended for printing, but to assist in printer design.

title: Waterproof beach storage tube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi,

this is a waterproof storage tube for your money or other things,
a nice gadget for beach, camping, prepper, or geocaching.

It is realy waterproof because of the o-ring.
You need a O-ring with a inner diameter of 31mm and thickness of 3,5 maybe a thickness
of 3mm would be easier to open and close the cap but i have dont test it.

!!IMPORTANT!! (fitting information)

I made the design wothout tolerances!
If you print it without scale it down the cap will not fit to the tube!
For the most printers a scale of 0,97 should be ok.
In Repetier Host you can scale induvidually for each axis.

So you should scale:

X : 0,97
Y: 0,97
Z: 1 >Don´t scale the Z axis!

If you scale the Z axis the pitch would be incorrect!

If the cap does not fit, dont worry.
scale the cap bigger or smaller and print only the cap again.

description.text:
This is set of simple brackets to join 30x30mm aluminium extrusion profiles with 8mm slot (i bought mine on http://ehlinik.cz).
Except corner bracket all printable without supports. Print corner bracket in orientation provided in stl for better strenght.
You will need M6x12 (or M6x14 with washer) screws and low-profile M6 nuts (DIN439).
For adjustable feet use M10 screw and nut. You have to add pause to gcode at height 9mm and insert nut inside. Above the nut is one solid layer for easier printing, cut it away by knife or simply let the screw break trough.

Nozzle_Length = 140

I started from AndyCart's PrntQB V2 9 months ago and have been making gradual "improvements" to end up at this. Some key features:

  1. The offset pulleys at the front avoid the string rubbing, this doesn't affect the corexy geometry.
  2. Aluminium carriages, I found the printer I used to make the initial carriages couldn't make straight holes so I turned to the milling machine.
  3. X Y carriage are 75mm wide the initials ones were 25mm and this proved much too narrow, resulting in significant slop at the print head.
  4. The bushes are simply made on a lathe from nylon rod with a 8.1mm hole.
  5. I'm currently trying dry lubricant to protect the silver steel rods from corrosion.
  6. The small 623 bearings are quite sloppy, the 625 ones are much better.
  7. After some experimentation with the Z drive the best configuration seems to be to have the threaded rod butted up against the motor shaft inside the flexible coupler. The bearing at the bottom stops the rod moving down when the carriage is being lifted.
  8. The brackets for the z axis are separate parts so that the spacing is only determined by the carriage.
  9. I've changed from a straight drive pulley to the figure of eight style idler. This stops the string moving up and down the drive pulley which seemed to be affecting the accuracy as the angles change. However this has been quite problematic to date, there seems to be a small amount of creep of the drive string on the pulley causing subsequent layers to become offset. I have since reverted to the old system of a plain pulley and no idler, this works much better but the accuracy isn't great (plus or minus about 0.3%). So good enough for a lot of things.
    Video: https://youtu.be/n_YZ6EtYQfY

Edit: Thingiverse isn't letting me post comments, to reply to mbthor:
Thanks. I've uploaded a video from before I reverted back to the old drive system. The groves were made using a tool with an insert which had a radius of roughly 0.5mm on, so they are rounded. My idler bearings/supports are poor and not entirely vertical which could be contributing, I'm not sure. With the idlers there is a much greater length of line between the in and out of the drive system which might have something to do with it.

I would really like a video of the thing printing, with some long shots on the spectra drive you have there. I thought this solution was dead a few years back. I am a big fan of spectra.

author: bombercan

description.text:
Here is "InMoov", the robot hand you can print and animate. You have a 3D printer, some building skills, This project is for you!!
This is a hand built for a job (still picture commercial), it was supposed to be mobile but not animated and mostly be able to take human hand positions. Cables or fishing rods might be added in order to control it, but it was not the purpose of this work at first. I am now working on another model(for the fun), trying to animate it, I really would like to do it with computer control but I have never worked in that field. Never used servo's before, so any help is welcomed.
Blog:
http://inmoov.blogspot.com IMPORTANT: Before printing these files, check my website for the latest updates.
Site:
http://www.inmoov.fr
A first movement video. I have to say that this video was not easy to do. I was holding the camera with one hand and trying to trigger the rods with the other.
I definitly need three hands!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r_rQ2WJ0dq4
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JztSQpwZaRU
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zvbNcuUPHyQ
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BAs2F4sFVdA
Last of all:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tojIdfywYVI
A demo using Leap motion to control the hand:
http://youtu.be/GOTRXM4O9L0
There is also the left hand model for the one that plan to make a complete robot, Arf, still quite a bite of work though.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18939

IMPORTANT: Before printing these files, check my website for the latest updates. This is a work in progress, files might change until it is finished.
Print one of each STL files attached. I did it in ABS.
Before printing read all this, since the updates are on the bottom, it might save you printing time.
Find a full tuto here:
http://www.inmoov.fr/hand-and-forarm/
Print wriargeV3, wristsmallV3,thumb4 with an infill of 30%, 3 shells, best with no support, no raft.
Print auriculaire3,index3,majeure3,ringfinger3 with an infill of 30%, 1 shell, best with no support, no raft.
Print robpart2V3, robpart3V3, robpart4V3, robpart5V3 with an infill of 30%, 3 shell, best with raft.
Print coverfinger with an infill of 30%, 3 shells, with support.
You will also need the rotational Wrist: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25149
And the simple servo support. Available here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:65274 Big bolts are now printable. (Strong enough for me.)
You can replace the 16x3mm for the fingers with pins/pegs of filament instead of bolts, it's cheap, easy, and strong enough. It was a suggestion of FreddyA.
1x8mmx8cm bolt is required for to attach wriarge to wristsmall.
1x8mmx4cm bolt is required for to attach wriarge to thumbbottom.
1x8mmx6cm bolt is required for to attach wriarge to robpart1.
16x3mmx2cm bolts are required for all fingers hinges(I have recut each bolt to adapt to finger width) Glue with acetone like on pictures:
Thumb4 flat parts together but Not the tip.
Finger flat parts but Not the tips(Be carefull not to mix them up, they all have a different size)
Redrill 8mm holes if needed.
If necessary reDrill all finger hinges with 3mm drill. If you plan on using filament pegs, redrill at 3mm(Be careful not to break parts)
Fingers should move freely.
26/02/12 Okay, I have added parts of the forarm, print without support but with raft. I have already set in some extra parts intended to support overhangs in robpart2V2, robpart3, robpart4V2, robpart5V2
Once printed remove the added supports and the anti-warp structures.
Make sure to remove only the added parts and not the servo brackets.
Redrill the brackets if necessary.
Glue with acetone Rotawrist, robpart2v3 and robpart5V3. Make sure the servo brakets are aligned.
Glue together robpart3V3 and robpart4V3.
Mount the simple servo bed.
Fit and bolt in the 4 servos HK15298.
Wire the servos to the exit of Robcap..
Run from each servos two rods of fishing Braid 200 LB to the tip of each finger. Make sure not to twist them on the way through. When passing the bolts of hinges, one rod has to be over and one has to be under. Add on each bolt a ring2 in the hinge. Set your servo in to max position suposedly with straight flat fingers with the horn set to full pull out. Secure the rods at the tip of fingers by making two knots + a drop of cyanocrylate glue. Rods have to be tight fit between the horn and tip of finger.
Once all fingers are wired through, glue the tips of fingers with acetone.
Mount the "topsurface" on the back of the hand with 3mmx2cm bolts.
Glue the coverfinger on top of fingers. Make sure movement is free with hinges. Update 15/03/12: Big Cover for the right hand ready and uploaded, servos and Arduino arrived and almost installed. Added little cable holders to glue, and an Arduino support (thanks to Jestin and pchretien)
Update 21/03/12 I redesigned robpart2 to robpart2V2 due to missing piece of bracket( Thanks Wulfnor)
Update 28/03/12 you can download the scripts for Arduino to either do the pattern motion shown in the last video or use your keyboard to control the servos.(you need to install serialterm for keyboard control)Thanks to Crazy Jaw for the help.
Update 01/04/12 of Wristsmall1 to WristsmallV2 avoids the motion from closing too much the hand. Also added holes for positionning topsurface4.
Update 02/04/12 of Wriarge1 to WriargeV2, added holes for positionning topsurface4 and two cages for nuts at end of 8mm bolts..
Update 18/05/12 printable bolts, changed "robpart4" to "robpart4V2" for to receive the arm piston. see blog
Update 16/06/12 I have uploaded the rotational wrist.
see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25149
Update 22/06/12 I have uploaded the new brackets and modified "robparts" mentionned on my blog.
see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25465
Update 22/06/12 Uploaded "robcap3V1" for to close the elbow of the forarm.
Update 23/06/12 Modified all the fingers2 to version3 for easy mounting, also modified wristlargeV2, wristsmallV2 to V3 version. All holes are ready, and the hinges are ready to be assembled. Rings are already set in the hinges.
Update 16/07/12 Modified thumb4 to thumb5, oddly it wouldn't fit into wristlargeV2 anymore. added the hole for attaching the cover.
Update 06/08/12 Added InMoovPowerGlove (Thanks to brianhomer)
The zip contains a PDF diagram for connections and a sketch to upload on your Arduino board.
Update 17/09/12 I have uploaded the bicep parts.
see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30654
Update 03/01/13 I have uploaded the shoulder parts.
see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40040
Update 20/01/13you can now download the torso parts at
https://cubehero.com/physibles/hairygael/Torso_for_Robot_InMoov
Update 27/02/13 you can now downoload the neck with mechanism
https://cubehero.com/physibles/hairygael/Neck_Mechanism_For_InMoov/print
Update 12/12/13 simple servo bed is now the default mount system for the servos. robparts are now changed to robpartV3 to simplify the comprehension. WristLargeV3 is changed to WristLargeV4, the linings inside for the rods is more simple and will not get mixed during pathing.
Rotawrist replaces robpart1.
Update 21/10/14 EntretoiseBolt6 to EntretoiseBolt7
Still working on instructions text...

comments.text: Why not put the joints on something like a galvanometer, instead of so many servos, just run some cables through them.
comments.author: SydneyMakersHub

comments.text: Not sure what you mean? - A galvanometer is a measurement device and a servo is a mechanical device (motor). How would you use a measurement device to move the fingers instead of the servo motors to move them?
comments.author: SydneyMakersHub

comments.text: Let's assume a traditional analog galvanometer, passing a current through the moving coil wire will push the needle to a certain position on the dial, in this case, we want to make the joint pivot around the dial, pass a current through the moving coil, and the joint hinges around it.
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: Interesting. If we look at the measurement tool (galvanometer) through a small electromagnetic field it moves a needle, a small needle, weighing micro-grams against a return coil spring exerting micro-grams/mm torque. With the robot fingers we are trying to copy the human condition to exert multiple Kilo-grams of torque per mm. The galvanometer is a measurement device and not a mechanical motion device. Or am I missing more? What mechanized machinery in manufacturing or motion control industries use a galvanometer as a motion device? A galvanometer does use the electromagnetic fields similar to an electric motor but, it is not a motion device to transmit power/torque to a machine.
comments.author: SydneyMakersHub

comments.text: It probably isn't a better option than stepper motors, but its nice to think of alternate methods of doing something, it can lead to new ideas
comments.author: bstott

comments.author: Bill_Devine

comments.text: They are not very tight. They allow smooth motion if printed properly. Others have made scaled down versions too. But, note that you can make them tight by tightening the screws you assemble the joints with. This is where you can get your ability to pose the joints.

comments.text: This robot is not cheap even when you have a printer but, you can get a start by buying an inexpensive printer and printing you InMoov parts. As time goes by you can amass the parts. You could also build yourself a 3D printer to get into the robotics. Many of the skills and much of the knowledge is transferable between the printers and the robot.
comments.author: Smartmiltoys

comments.text: Not sure what area you're in, but see if you can find a local maker through www.makexyz.com.  I know they have listings in the United States, not sure about their coverage in other countries.
comments.author: Smartmiltoys

comments.text: This is an OK idea to look for local makers. Also, local clubs rent equipment or have memberships which you can then use their facilities. Note that most Maker people are makers and making their own things. They, many, will take on small prints and projects but, this robot is not something someone will likely print for you to be a 'Swell Person.' Not because they are not but, because the items take a long time to print. And take up a fair amount of plastic. So, you will be charged for the work and this you may not find too appealing for building your own robot. Most of us who have the robot in making have our own tools and build ourselves. So, to build you have to be a builder. Welcome to the Maker community. ;-) Jump in - the waters fine!

comments.text:
Hi,
You need to adjust the Arduino sketch to have minimum and maximum or whatever soft you are using. The HK15298 servos have a restricted rotation of 90 degrees but the MG996R (for exemple) don't have that restriction. They can rotate from 0 to 180 degree. That is why it is necessary to use the software to adjust the servos degree rotations.

comments.text: .stl is also an extension used by microsoft for security certificates and is usually associated to another application in Windows. Download the 'all files' zip and then, after extracting, right click and select 'open with...' From there you can select whatever application you want to open the stl with. There should be an option to set your selected application to open all files of this type. Or, as mentioned, you can open your 3d application first, then use its 'Open' dialog to select from wherever you unzipped your archive.

comments.text:
Hey thanks for the reply. I have since gotten my own 3D printer and am working on printing the parts out.
I also modeled my skeletal parts and am working on finding a way to print them really accurately even though they have basically no flat surfaces, and getting the settings on my printer just right to print them as perfectly as I can. I am going to do lost-PLA aluminum casting for them for the arm so it's more robust than printed parts.
Here's a screenshot of my model of the hand: http://i.imgur.com/dVGocoF.jpghttp://i.imgur.com/dVGocoF.jpg
It's a work in progress but that's what I have so far. The fingertips will be shaped like fingertips instead of the bones. That's why there's no joint between the last two bones yet.
I also abandoned the Power Glove idea and plan on using a combination of an EEG headset and EMG sensors for muscles. Still going with air muscles but I have to get the skeleton made before I can try them out on anything.
Do you happen to know where I could see the air muscle projects you mentioned?

Very interesting project. It would be a good idea to replace the servos with stepper motors for more precision and strength. On the fingertips some pressure sensors (piezo??) could be attached. The whole thing should be controlled by are ÂµC with a CAN interface. The CAN bus connects all ÂµCs in the robot (one for each body part, hand, arm, etc.), in the head a stronger processor like an Rasperry Pi could be connected to CAN network controlling movement, interfacing etc.
I'm currently working with ARM ÂµCs like the LPC13xx and LPC17xx series, they would fit very good, as they have a CAN interface.

author: cmatthews19

description.text:
Since extending the Z-axis on my wanhao i3 printer I discovered that there was a small amount of ringing toward the middle of the axis when printing at high speeds. To alleviate this I decided to use the feed screw to provide extra support.

I did this by putting a small bearing block at the top of the axis. However for this to work you will want to check that your feed screws are perfectly straight, this is easily done by putting it against the straight edge of a ruler or on a piece of glass. The bearings for the block are 8mm ID x 16mm OD x 5mm Wide MR688ZZ. These should be available online from most hobby stores as they are fitted to many model helicopters.

While doing this modification I also moved the X-axis bearing rod holders to the outside of the carrier, this was to make it simpler to tighten the locking grubscrews, and to allow me to invert the Z-axis nuts. By putting the Z-axis nuts inside the carrier it was possible to conserve height. I turned one of the bearing rod holders upside down and countersunk the heads of the screws, this freed up an extra 4mm of travel on the X-axis.

To mount the bearing blocks you will want to extend the X-gantry up so that only 10mm or so of the feed screw is protruding. Fit the bearing block over the feed screw, then place the top plate with the bearing rod holder on top, this will align everything nice and parallel. I used a little bit of hot glue to hold the bearing block onto the top plate so that I could mark the position for the screw holes. Using a 3.5mm drill make the four holes in each plate, then using 15mm M3 bolts and matching M3 nuts lightly bolt the bearing blocks to the top plate. Fit the plate with bearing block back over the bearing rod and feed screw before tightening the bolts up, this will make sure that everything is perfectly aligned.

It's simply a matter of bolting the top back onto the printer and checking that the Z-axis moves up and down freely without any resistance.
