author: Papyrus29

description.text:
Space Goggles of Awesomeness

The first time I saw a Neopixel ring I knew I would build a pair of goggles with them. The folks at Adafruit must have had the same thought, because they now sell a kit that includes a pair of costume goggles, a pair of Neopixel rings, and (almost) everything you need to make a cool pair of glasses.

https://www.adafruit.com/products/2221

They will amaze your friends and confuse your enemies. Unfortunately, the kit doesn't include a way to mount the rings in the goggles. Scotch tape worked Ok, but visibility through the goggles was very poor. The villains were still getting away!

These printable mounting ring inserts hold the rings securely in the goggles without any messy tape, and they improve visibility with a tube to reduce direct and reflected glare.

The case can be discretely attached to the strap to hold the controller and battery securely while you're apprehending bad guys.

I added an SPDT to switch the power ON or OFF to conserve battery charge on longer missions. When you return to your lair, remember that the battery can only be charged when the power is OFF.

I also added a small momentary contact pushbutton between pin #3 and GND. A slow button press longer than 1/2 second will toggle automatic color pattern cycling ON and OFF. A quick button press will advance the color pattern manually.

Construction

NOTE: These instructions involve soldering live battery leads. Extreme caution must be taken to avoid shorting the battery as this can damage the electronics and/or cause serious personal injury! If you are not comfortable doing this, simply omit the SPDT power switch, don't cut the battery leads, and assemble your kit according to the Adafruit instructions.

Print a pair of Neopixel eye surrounds and a controller case and lid. These are provided as an all-in-one STL for your convenience. The eyepieces have slots that will align with the wires of the Neopixel rings and allow the wiring to exit cleanly from the back of the Neopixel PCBs. After wiring and assembly, they can be inserted into the goggle body and will be held in place by the screw-on lens cover.

The Trinket case has slots so it can be attached to the goggle strap. You may find it easier to attach the case to the strap before you install the SPDT power switch and other components. The Adafruit costume goggle strap has a metal cap on each end. (Or maybe it's an "aglet?") It may be necessary to temporarily remove one cap to facilitate disassembly and reassembly of the goggle strap. Gently bend the cap open to remove it. Unwind one end of the strap from the goggles, wind through the case slots as shown, and then reassemble the strap.

Construction is similar to the Adafruit kit, but with an added SPDT power switch (Radio Shack p/n 275-0635 or similar) and a momentary contact pushbutton. Both switches are optional - the firmware presented here will work (with reduced functionality) if you decide not to install either one.

Unlike the Adafruit instructions, do not solder the battery connector onto the bottom of the Trinket as this will interfere with the placement of the battery. Instead, solder wires directly onto the Trinket PCB. The connector that is cut off the battery will be reattached to connect the charger.

The pushbutton is wired directly onto the edge of the Trinket between pin #3 and GND. It is a good idea to test fit the switch in the case before soldering. The unused contacts on the other side of the button should be removed. Because the pushbutton now occupies the GND thru-hole, you may wish to connect the black power input GND wire onto the "-" contact on the underside of the controller board.

When wiring the SPDT power switch, take special care not to short the battery! Do not cut or strip both battery leads at the same time!

0.) Use heat shrink tubing to insulate all connections and switch terminals as you go.
1.) Cut the red lead about halfway between the battery and the connector.
2.) Solder the battery red wire to the center contact of the SPDT switch.
3.) Solder the charge connector red wire to either side of the SPDT.
4.) Solder a wire from the other side of the SPDT to the "BAT" contact on the Trinket, along with the "V+" connector to the Neopixel ring. You may prefer to add a short lead from the Trinket to the wire junction.
5.) Cut the black lead about halfway between the battery and connector and strip both sides.
6.) Wind them together with the "GND" lead to the Neopixel rings and connect them to the "-" contact on the underside of the Trinket board.

For the Trinket you need to use the Arduino 1.6 or later IDE. Under the Tools menu, set the Programmer to "USBTinyISP" and the Board to "Adafruit Trinket 16MHz." The Port name may depend on your operating system. With the SPDT power OFF, connect the USB and watch for flashing red LEDs on the Trinket as you hit Download in the IDE.

The Neopixel ring cannot take power off of the USB port, so you won't see anything until you switch the SPDT to battery power. When you turn it ON, the rings should begin cycling through color patterns after a ~2 second boot time.

Mount the SPDT in the case. Put the battery into the well and secure with double-sided tape if desired. Then mount the Trinket above the battery and secure with two small screws. The screws will self-tap into the undersized plastic guide holes. Ensure that the momentary switch is aligned with the access hole and operates without interference.

The cover will snap into place, and can be secured with glue or tape if desired.

NOTE: Any form of costume eyewear can reduce visibility for the wearer which can pose a hazard to young trick-or-treaters on dark streets. Fortunately, these goggles look just as cool when worn on the forehead as they do over the eyes, and the flashing lights will help motorists and passing aircraft to see your child in the dark.

Happy Halloween!

 //
 //  Adapted from the Adafruit Low Power NeoPixel Goggles example.
 //
 //  This uses a Trinket 5V and a pair of Flora Neopixel 16-element rings
 //  to turn an ordinary pair of aviation, welders', or costume goggles
 //  into something extraordinary.
 //
 //  Added support for a momentary-contact pushbuttton from pin #3 to GND.
 //  Pressing this button for longer than 1/2 second toggles in and out of
 //  automatic color sequencing mode.  A shorter button press advances the
 //  color sequence manually.
 //
 //  When adding color patterns, remember that power consumption and battery life
 //  are affected by the number and intensity of pixels that are lit.
 //

  #include <Adafruit_NeoPixel.h>
  #ifdef __AVR_ATtiny85__ // Trinket, Gemma, etc.
   #include <avr/power.h>
  #endif

  // Define the digital I/O pin connected to the Neopixel string:
  #define NEOPIXEL_PIN      (0)
  // Each eyepiece has 16 Neopixel LEDs, so initialize a chain of 32:
  #define NEOPIXEL_COUNT    (2*16)
  Adafruit_NeoPixel pixels = Adafruit_NeoPixel(NEOPIXEL_COUNT, NEOPIXEL_PIN);

  // We have a momentary contact pushbutton on I/O pin #3: (shared with USB!)
  #define PIN_BUTTON_A 3

   uint32_t pressTime;
  int buttonState = 0;  // 0=released, 1=debounce, 2=pressed

  uint8_t  mode   = 0, // Current animation effect
           offset = 0; // Position of spinny eyes
  //uint32_t color  = 0xFF0000; // Start red
  #define N_COLORS  (7)
  uint32_t colors[N_COLORS]  =
  {
    0xFF0000,  // Red
    0xFFFF00,  // Yellow
    0x00FF00,  // Green
    0x00FFFF,  // Cyan
    0x0000FF,  // Blue
    0xFF00FF,  // Magenta
    0xFFFFFF,  // White
  };
  int nColor = 0;
  uint32_t prevTime;
  int autoMode = 1;

  void advanceMode()
  {
      mode++;                        // Next mode
      if (mode > 1)
      {                 // End of modes?
        mode = 0;                    // Start modes over
      }
      {
        //color >>= 8;                 // Next color R->G->B
        //if(!color) color = 0xFF0000; // Reset to red
        nColor++;
        if (nColor >= N_COLORS)
          nColor = 0;
      }

      for (uint8_t i=0; i<32; i++)
      {
        pixels.setPixelColor(i, 0);
      }
  }

  void setup() {
  #ifdef __AVR_ATtiny85__ // Trinket, Gemma, etc.
    if(F_CPU == 16000000) clock_prescale_set(clock_div_1);
  #endif

    // Set pushbutton pin as input:
    pinMode(PIN_BUTTON_A, INPUT_PULLUP);
    // Setting input pins to high turns on internal pull-up resistors:
    digitalWrite(PIN_BUTTON_A, HIGH);

    pixels.begin();
    pixels.setBrightness(85); // 1/3 brightness
    prevTime = millis();
  }

  void loop() {
    uint8_t  i;
    uint32_t t;

    t = millis();

    // Must debounce the button on Pin #3 in case we're powered off USB of an actual computer.
    // The USB host will pulse the data line and fake us out otherwise.
    if (digitalRead(PIN_BUTTON_A) == LOW)
    {
      if (buttonState == 0)
      {
        pressTime = t;
        buttonState = 1;
      }
      else if ((buttonState == 1) && ((t - pressTime) >= 3000 + 60))
      {
        // Long hold detected (> 3 seconds)
        //buttonState = 2;
      }
    }
    else
    {
      if (buttonState == 1)
      {
         // Long click (> 1/2 second) changes mode:
         if ((t - pressTime) >= 500+60)
         {
             // Auto color / mode change every 8 seconds ON / OFF
             autoMode = !autoMode;
             prevTime = t;  // Reset next auto-change to 8 seconds
             // If entering auto mode, cycle (almost) immediately:
             if (autoMode)
             {
                 prevTime = t - 7000;  // If I could turn back time...
             }
         }
         // Short click (> 60 msec) changes color:
         else if ((t - pressTime) >= 60)
         {
            // Advance to the next color or mode
            advanceMode();
             prevTime = t;  // Reset next auto-change to 8 seconds
         }
      }
      buttonState = 0;
    }

    switch (mode)
    {
     case 0: // Random sparks - just one LED on at a time!
      i = random(32);
      pixels.setPixelColor(i, colors[nColor]);
      pixels.show();
      delay(10);
      pixels.setPixelColor(i, 0);
      break;

     case 1: // Spinny wheels (8 LEDs on at a time)
      for (i=0; i<16; i++)
      {
        uint32_t c = 0;
        if (((offset + i) & 7) < 2)
        {
          c = colors[nColor]; // 4 pixels on...
        }
        pixels.setPixelColor(   i, c); // First eye
        pixels.setPixelColor(31-i, c); // Second eye (flipped)
      }
      pixels.show();
      offset++;
      delay(50);
      break;
    }

    if (autoMode)  // Are we in auto-cycle mode?
    {
      // Check if it is time to cycle to a new mode:
      if ((t - prevTime) > 8000)    // Every 8 seconds...
      {
        advanceMode();
        prevTime = t;
      }
    }
  }

So here i'm explaining this tool.

Here is my new idea that was very problematic for me, i wanted some sort of test tube that can be carried easily in my bag or pocket for multiples tasks like collecting plants seeds, little leaf and flower but for other tasks.
Extremly usefull because it can be sealed and waterproof. It can containt things dry without problem.

Concerning the fillet there will be no probleme even if you have unprecise 3D printer or a poor quality of printing ;)

Internal diameter 16mm OR 18mm diam/45 mm deep

It can be resised without affecting problem, the fillet is made of my work
I use for all my conseption a standart fillet, 3.33 mm for the pas, and triangle shape with 3mm base 2.5 to 3mm eigh
The two parts together is 51mm heigh. Far the smallest tube. Heigh are told in the picture.

I also add two tiny grip on the lid for people who want to add this to wear on a belt .

title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 Bowden Extruder for E3D V6 / Clone

description.text:
Wanhao Duplicator I3 Bowden Extruder for E3D V6 / Clone

I wanted to install a Bowden extruder on my i3 but I had some requirements of my own. I couldn't find one that meet all the requirements so I set out to make a hybrid of two great mounts by JonBAL and Tech2C. So I present the ChandersV6R0!

Skills Needed
  1. Patience
  2. Soldering
  3. Troubleshooting
Tools Needed
  1. Standard set of allen keys provided by Wanhao
  2. Soldering iron / solder / heat shrink
  3. Snips
  4. 3D printer to print the parts
Parts Needed
  1. E3D v6 (J-head) hotend for 1.75mm
    Comes with cooling fan, heat break, heating block, heater cartridge, nozzle, PTFE tube for 1.75mm
  2. Some cable management tubing
  3. M3 and M4 nuts screws and bolts of assorted lengths
  4. 12V DC 50mm Blower Radial Cooling Fan
Parts Reused
  1. M4 screws that hold existing assembly to the bearing block
  2. M2 screws for X-Axis Endstop
  3. Thermistor (I didn't want to recompile the firmware for another thermistor)
    The stock heater will not fit the new heating block so you will need to get one with the kit

READ IMPORTANT!

This mount changes the Z and Y distances of the hotend. You WILL need to print replacement mounts for the end stops. I used these two

Z - Here
Y - In STLs

DO THIS NOW!!

Extruder Stepper Motor Mount

Once we remove the assembly we will need to find somewhere to put the extruder stepper motor. I used these. NOTE these mounts are made for a specific pneumatic fitting diameter. MAKE SURE the one you print will fit your pneumatic fitting.

X-Axis Belt Mount

Once we remove the assembly we will need to find somewhere to anchor the X-Axis belts. The assembly has two M4 hole locations that will be used to zip tie the belts to. NOTE I printed this section of the mount at 100% infill since it will have to bear the forces of the tightened belts. I also used these tensioners to tension the belts when complete.

Bearing Mount

This assembly is for a Wanhao i3 and clones V2.1. If you have an i3 that is <2.1 you may need to print bearing mounts ( or not as you may be able to line up the holes on the assembly).

Things to note

Removing the cables from the drag chain is a B%$#&! I had to remove the connectors on the open end, pull them through and re solder them. You will need to get creative. OR you can take the chain apart, your choice.

You will need to solder the new heater cartridge to the existing wires from the old heater cartridge. Make sure to heat shrink it or use electrical tape.

I used Kapton tape to keep the wires tidy close to the hot end and zip ties higher up.

The assembly that holds the extruder in place may be a little tight or slightly slack depending on if you are using a real V6 or a clone. Once its tightened it will work perfectly.

I am continuously improving the design so the pictures may not match the STLs 100%.

I left out steps that I thought were simple but if you have any questions or need clarifications please feel free to let me know!

Please let me know if you made one!

Printer:

Wanda Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

65%

Notes:

You will need to print the section of the mount where the M4 bolts hold the X-Axis belts at 100% for strength due to the tightening forces.

You will need to print a section of the fan duct with supports.
I didn't include the hose clamps as these will need to be custom sized for your cable management,

description.text:
If unsure what to do: print the file set_chinese_cross.stl and try to solve the puzzle.

The 6-piece Burr interlocking puzzles are made of six (usually wooden) notched sticks that should be reassembled in a threedimensional object where the sticks hold each other in place. Usually only one can be removed which is the start of the disassembling.

A special case is the solid burr puzzle which does not contain any holes in its internal when reassembled. It is known that there exist 314 configurations of six pieces that build up a solid burr. These 314 configurations can be built from 25 different so called notchable pieces, which can be found in notchable25set.stl. However, some pieces are needed twice or at most three times to build up any solid burrs. Therefore I included the notchable42set.stl which hold some duplicate pieces. These are enough to reassemble all the 314 solid burrs.

Apart from this complete set I included several standard 6-piece minisets that form one of the 314 possible solid burrs. Thus, printing one of these 6-piece sets is one complete burr puzzle. Finally you can find STL-files for each of the 25 pieces separately. One can, for instance, print the sticks in different colors.

Well known 6-piece burr puzzles (between brackets the pieces included in the set):

  • diabolical_structure (1,256,256,256,928,928)
  • chinese_cross (1,256,824,975,928,1024)
  • six_way_set (52,792,911,824,975,1024)
  • yamato_block (1,188,824,975,1024,1024)

Other six-piece burr designs (between brackets the pieces included in the set):

  • love_s_dozen (88,512,704,960,992,1008)
  • piston_burr (88,512,768,922,1008,1008)
  • computer_s_choice_unique_10 (624,702,768,883,1015,1024)
  • baffling_burr_puzzle (52,615,792,960,992,975)
  • hoffmann_burr (1,188,256,960,975,1024)
  • philippe_dubois (120,160,256,512,880,960)
  • tenyo_brother (463,564,760,909,927,1016)
  • double_cross (1,154,256,256,1024,1024)
  • artifactory_5_4 (412,480,512,704,704,960)

I added the SCAD-file as well such that you can define your own set or create other pieces than the standard 25 notchable ones. In de SCAD-file it is possible to change the size, the predefined gap between the pieces (to allow for printing errors) and the rounding radius of the edges. Moreover you may choose four difference stick bases. The burr "chinese cross" has been included in base 1, 2 and 3 as well (see base[n]*.stl files).

More information about burr puzzles can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burr_puzzle
I'd like to refer to Rob's Puzzle page which is an excellent website about (among other things) Burr puzzles: http://www.robspuzzlepage.com/interlocking.htm
Finally there is a website of Bill Cutler who did a lot of research on this topic. See http://www.billcutlerpuzzles.com/ or http://www.cs.brandeis.edu/~storer/JimPuzzles/BURR/000BURR/NOTES/WebPagesExpanded/CutlerComputerAnalysis-ALL.pdf

For some reason the controls does not show up in the customizer. I am working on it. If anyone has any idea...

Notes:

There are a few pieces that need support.

title: The eternal sunshine of the turret spot

description.text: I needed some new lighting so I printed it. ;-) I printed it with rather thick walls out of concern for the PLA melting. This has not happened with the spots in upright (lamp on top) positions. However, be careful about this. You can optionally add a screen with the stylized profile of a cat, a bat, or whatever night critter happens to be your fave.

You will need 1 x base and either 1 x cylinderslots or 1 x cylinderholes.
Uses 2 x M4x25 bolts , 2 x m4 nuts and 4 to 6 x m4 washers.
Fits a type of spotlight commonly seen here. Use a fluorescent or led source..
Please bear in mind that if you insist in using it with a 50W halogen source, especially in an inverted position, the plastic may melt, a short may result, your house may burn down to tiny ashes, and / or your country may start nuking innocent people. This is released with NO responsability of what you may do with it.

description.text:
Strumento per riconoscere la polarità (positiva/negativa) massimo voltaggio con la resistenza 4.7 Kohms è di 12V.

Componenti:
-2 Led rossi
-una resistenza da 4.7 Kohms (in base alle vostre esigenze)
-una pinza
-un cavo

Funzionamento;

Collegare il capo del "Tester" a un capo sul quale si vuole riconosce la polarità, con la seconda estremità del "Tester" andare a toccare il capo opposto del circuito, il quale vi dirà la rispettiva polarità in base al led acceso.

Tool for recognizing the polarity (positive / negative) maximum voltage with resistance 4.7 Kohms is 12V.

components:
-2 Red LEDs
-resistance from 4.7 Kohms (according to your needs)
-gripper
-cable

operation;

Connect the head of the "tester" to a head on which you want to recognize the polarity, with the second end of the "tester" to tamper with the opposite end of the circuit, which will tell you the respective polarity according to the led on.

comments.text: I'm sorry, I'm not familiar with SCAD and parametric stuff yet. Which files do I need to build this with Mk8/1.75?
comments.author: Velkahn

comments.text:
Hi,
i made one of this feeder today, but it seems like there are some design issues.
First one are the gears:
I do printed these with no clearance in openscad script, but my gears came out small. I still have a gap between the gears, but cant move the motor closer to the main part, because it is already in closest position.
So i made a new small gear with same modul and 2 more teeth.
Next thing is setting the gear distance with motor mount/adjustment screws.
I built the thing up and then i cant reach the screws down underneath the big gear. And if i need to get the big gear off, in this design you must rip off all parts and disassemble the whole thing.
Last thing is MK8 gear. The deep groove of mk8 gear get up deep inside the body, so the filament cant get straight throu and will be bent downwards. So some of the gained torque from the gears will be lost in friction within the feeder.
comments.author: gafu

comments.text:
Hi
it's so strange - because i have printed published stl for my version:
nema17, mk8 1.75, bearings 625zz
and use it with no troubles
comments.author: gafu

comments.text:
hi and thanks for answering.
First some additional information.
I managed to get my printing parts to nearly axact measures by negative xy-size-compensation values in slic3r advanced settings at around half of layer-thickness. (so at 0.2mm layers -0.1 xy-size-compensation)
comments.author: akajes

comments.text:
its me again.
i investigated further and made some measurements.
comments.author: gafu

comments.text:
Clearance must be corrected for various type of plastics and nozzle size
by default i use for holes +nozzle for rods and etc -nozzle.
I have the same mk8 sizes but use 1.75 filament.
filament_diameter = 1.75 + clearance; //clearance here need to prevent bending filament
When you change to it 3 - motor distance will not change against increase space for idler.
For minimizing distance between motor and main part you can switch on
show_motor=1;
and play with
motor_distane=-20+gear[3];
it depend on bearing kind size.
My motor size about 42.5mm nema17 and i have free space between motor and main part 1-2mm
Maybe your slicer have some global size correction coefficients(if it exists)?
comments.author: gafu

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Flat Spool Holder

description.text:
I wanted to make something to be able to lay my spool of filament flat on my printer so I can fit it in an enclosure with a low roof.
This uses the existing holes and the original screws so you don't need anything extra at all.

This is two parts with the filament_holder being 30.48mm (1.2in) spools and then the adapter being 53.34mm (2.1in) for the use of spools with bigger holes like Hatchbot.

9/18/2016
Added a 36.83mm (1.45in) adapter for rolls that are 1.5in in diameter

11/30/2016
Added a version with a guide for the filament based off the original. I have not tested this yet since I have no issues with the original one. Version with slot and without slot.
Added 50mm adapter version

Let me know if you think I should make any revisions to the parts or want a different adapter size.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10-15%

author: maurom

description.text:
I wanted to make a dial to keep track of hit points for some big monsters. I figured the HPs would be over 100, so I made three dials.

I put these together in Tinkercad. There are nubbins on one side and indentations on the other so that the dials will rotate and "stick."

The idea was that I would pass a rubberband through the three dials and then secure them on either end behind the disks with the arrows. The little "batarang" bits would hold onto the rubberband and provide tension.

I can't get it to print, however, without it sticking horribly to the raft. It prints fine, but I haven't been able to assemble and test one.

At Zandbroz Variety in downtown Sioux Falls, I frequently visit to find things to photograph. In the rear of the store is a small antiques and vintage section. I saw this charming little fellow in the clearance cart and decided to model him.

I set him in a spot with indirect lighting to ensure no blown out highlights or dark shadows. I set down a scale card I always carry around with me and proceeded to take 58 photos with my iPhone 6 Plus.

At home, I skimmed the photos for blurriness and then exported them into a folder on my desktop. I opened all the photos and stripped out the location data in the EXIF so Photoscan wouldn't get confused.

I imported the folder in Photoscan and set it to "High" for all steps. The only variation was during mesh creation when used the "Moderate" setting instead of the "Aggressive."

After the mesh was finished, I found that there were a lot of dimples, craters and odd artifacts that needed to be edited. I exported the model as an OBJ into Meshmixer and worked on it. When I was satisfied with the results, I saved it as a new OBJ and then imported it back into Photoscan.

I then proceeded with the texture creation. My setting in the texture box was to average out the photos for color correction and to go up to 8192 to gain the best detail possible.

This thing a readaptation of Spindle Bearing Hub by neredera providing:

  • a more elastic surface for mounting the bearing (UPDATE: improved homing for safer mount)
  • a more elastic surface for fitting to spindle,
  • parametric design (OpenSCAD) just like its predecessor, to fit to your spindle hole diameter and bearing diameters.

Also inspired by HTA3D P3Steel bearing adapters.

The printed sample in the photo is made of two halves (PETG) that perfectly fit one another, balancing the forces over the bearings and avoiding unwanted side movements.

If you own a P3steel (HTA3D is my model) and are looking for a filament holder, I tried some designs but I ultimately found the best solution in adding approx. 50cm of Teflon filament sheating like you can see in the attached photos. That way your filament will run smoothy even when the X axis will do a full sweep. Also, you'll be able to reach high Z levels without any filament curving problem.

description.text: Many thanks for the original design!! I added a shark head protruding from the front for Shark Patrol.

Printer:

MakerFarm 12

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Added a 45-90 degree rotation on the supports to make them easier to remove from inside and outside the shark mouth.

How I did it

I used MeshMixer.

... imported the original Boy Scout slide and the shark, then used the "plane cut" tool to delete the body of the shark.
... used the "transform" tool to rotate and align the shark head to the plane of the slide.
... used the "view objects" window to merge the objects together.
... used the "make solid" tool to render the solid object
... exported the object as an STL.

A sculpture designed to be a lamp; see the instructions.  Could be used as a sculpture.  I printed it out in two tone; blue and florescent blue.  Tourou is the Japanese name for lamp.  
Version 2 has a side cut out so it is easier to get the wires inside the lamp.  
Made in Modo.

This needs no supports, it worked fine on my Rep 2. Probably best to print out at a large size because of the thickness of the top spheres and that will allow for larger bulb. T-Glass:
Some of the photos are of the model printed in Taulman 3D T-GLASE PETT
http://filaments.ca/collections/taulman-3d/products/taulman-3d-t-glase-pett-orion-blue-0-45kg-spool
Here are the settings that worked with my Rep 2:
Temp 238 (I found that 230 was too low and resulted in poor quality - styrofoam like quality)
Speed: 30 mm/s
quality: .3 mm (the thicker extrusion was the suggestion by Talman for a more transparent look and it worked fine till the top when it is more horizontal)
2 shells
10% infill Turning it into a table lamp or nightlight:
Materials:
  • two prong led light socket (Home Depot)
  • 12 V transformer (The Source or Home Depot)
  • on/off switch (Home Depot)
  • any wires for lengthening the distance from the light to the wall plug
  • 12V led light (in this case there are two led lights as part of the bulb - Home Depot) (larger ones won't fit)
    • Get a 12 V transformer, - one option is from The Source (Radio Shack) and another from Home Depot's light department (used for led lights). Purchased a 12V led light, the one in the picture is the perfect size for the default size of the print, make sure it is the right size to just fit the first level hole of the print. I included holes in the back for the wires - it is probably best to tie it off there so it is doesn't get accidentally pulled. Wired the 12V transformer to a two prong light socket, (see images) and then hot glued the outer rim of the led light and quickly pushed it up into the light house from below into the the first level hole to affix it. I also added an on/off switch, which can be purchased in the same area as the two prong light socket at Home Depot. The light does get hotter than expected so this could cause problems with the hot glue but we shall see, so far so good. Update: don't use hot glue if you leave the light on for any length of time. The led lights get hotter than I thought they would and it melts the hot glue. I will have to rethink this problem. ...I have now created a led light stand for this purpose: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:602016

description.text: This is a simplified version of Luke Skywalker's light saber in the 6th movie. I simplified it in a few key areas making it much easier to print. The light saber itself stands at just under a foot tall. It is easy to assemble this model as well. I have cut the lightsaber into 6 parts, numbered #1-6. 1 attaches on to 2, 2 to 3, 3 to 4, and so on. I have included pictures of what it looks like separated, and when it is put together in the proper order. I have included pins in each of the parts with a corresponding hole. The pins will center each parts so that it can be put together accurately, however, you will need to use some sort of glue for each of the 6 parts to hold them together. (I used abs cement). I have also put a little hole in the bottom of the lightsaber so you could use something like a paperclip to clip it onto your belt. This is not exactly the model from the movie, but it is very similar. You may need to scale it some based on the size of you hand, to get it to the right size for you. I hope you enjoy the model!!

title: Panasonic Sonicare Charger Holder for Shelf

description.text: Between my electric toothbrush, my beard trimmer, and my electric razor, the bathroom sink countertop is a bit crowded. I'd like to move them up to a shelf, but I don't want to have trouble with the chargers shifting as I try to put the items into them, or take them out. Hence, this design. It fits the charger for my Panasonic Sonicare toothbrush snugly enough that I can screw the holder to a shelf, then snap the charger into it, and it won't move. There's a gap in the back for the power cable. Once I do designs for the other two items, it'll be time to put up a shelf!

Ever need to print a cylindrical hole that changes to a smaller diameter part way up, and need your slicer to do something sensible with it? I found myself needing to do it a lot (screw-holes in the bottom of things for example), so I created this bit of OpenSCAD code (now a customiser) to generate it quickly. It transitions from the wider diameter to the narrower one using two layers that encourage your slicer to do some sensible bridging.

I use it to create an STL, then import it into my modelling software. It's not meant for printing directly!

This is a very specific print, but figured I'd upload it anyway with the sketchup file so you can try to make it work for you, or at least throw the idea out there for anyone who wants to make their own. This is a support for the GPU in Anidees AI Crystal pc enclosure. I'm sure it'll be close with any case that has a hidden PSU, but the motherboard may vary. This particular version measures 91mm.

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

50

Notes:

For anyone using the flashforge creator pro and simplify3d, I use the following script to get much cleaner prints. Adds more time as it lets one side cool down upon tool change, but it's worth it. I printed in abs, so if you're printing in PLA you will have to adjust the temps.... Just go to process settings, scripts, tool change script and copy the following.

; Tool chance script start
G1 X120 Y-70 F4000 ; Move out of the way while it stabilises active tool temp.
{IF NEWTOOL=0}; RIGHT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S160 T1; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T1)
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S230 T0; Heat active extruder to 210c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M133 T0; Stabilise T0 temperature
{IF NEWTOOL=1}; LEFT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S160 T0; Cool inactive extruder to 160c (T0)
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S230 T1; Heat active extruder to 230c (T0).
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M133 T1; Stabilise T1 temperature
; Tool chance script end

Assembly

Print 4 edge brackets and 2 corner brackets. I used a 258mm x 214mm sheet of clear 3mm lexan for the insert. Use clear silicon to glue the whole thing together.
